nodes: Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) CP module version 3.0
Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) level IV and V
directed_edges: Individuals with severe cerebral palsy (CP) often experience various health issues, including feeding difficulties
Individuals with severe cerebral palsy (CP) often experience various health issues, including feeding difficulties, which can adversely affect their nutritional status

Individuals with severe cerebral palsy (CP) often experience various health issues, including feeding difficulties, which can adversely affect their nutritional status and caregivers' quality of life, e.g., more time spent for feeding rather than own selfcare.
Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) level IV and V
Seventy-one participants with Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) level IV and V were recruited.
In total, 40.8% were underweight according to CP growth chart
In total, 40.8% were underweight according to CP growth chart and 49.3% had mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) readings below the 5th percentile.
The lowest scores in the PedsQL CP module version 3.0 were observed in the Daily Activities
Poor nutritional status in individuals with severe CP has been shown to negatively impact caregivers' quality of life.

Poor nutritional status in individuals with severe CP has been shown to negatively impact caregivers' quality of life. Therefore, a multidisciplinary approach involving nutritional intervention is essential to improve dietary provision and the nutritional status of children with CP.

Individuals with severe cerebral palsy (CP) often experience various health issues, including feeding difficulties, which can adversely affect their nutritional status
Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) CP module version 3.0
Poor nutritional status in individuals with severe CP has been shown to negatively impact caregivers' quality of life.
In total, 40.8% were underweight according to CP growth chart
The lowest scores in the PedsQL CP module version 3.0 were observed in the Daily Activities (5.34±10.87)
Sociodemographic and anthropometric data, including body mass index (BMI)-for-age, MUAC, body fat, triceps, and subscapular skinfold measurement, were predictors for the School Activities domain
Therefore, a multidisciplinary approach involving nutritional intervention is essential to improve dietary provision and the nutritional status of children with CP.

Poor nutritional status in individuals with severe CP has been shown to negatively impact caregivers' quality of life

Sociodemographic and anthropometric data, including body mass index (BMI)-for-age, MUAC, body fat, triceps, and subscapular skinfold measurement, were predictors for the School Activities domain [F (11, 44)=3.981, P<0.005, R2=0.499]. Poor nutritional status in individuals with severe CP has been shown to negatively impact caregivers' quality of life.

Sociodemographic and anthropometric data, including body mass index (BMI)-for-age, MUAC, body fat, triceps, and subscapular skinfold measurement, were predictors for the School Activities domain [F (11, 44)=3.981, P<0.005, R2=0.499].
Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) level IV and V
Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) CP module version 3.0
Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) CP module version 3.0
Poor nutritional status in individuals with severe CP has been shown to negatively impact caregivers' quality of life.

Sociodemographic and anthropometric data, including body mass index (BMI)-for-age, MUAC, body fat, triceps, and subscapular skinfold measurement, were predictors for the School Activities domain [F (11, 44)=3.981, P<0.005, R2=0.499].
In total, 40.8% were underweight according to CP growth chart and 49.3% had mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) readings below the 5th percentile.

Poor nutritional status in individuals with severe CP has been shown to negatively impact caregivers' quality of life. Therefore, a multidisciplinary approach involving nutritional intervention is essential to improve dietary provision and the nutritional status of children with CP.

Sociodemographic and anthropometric data, including body mass index (BMI)-for-age, MUAC, body fat, triceps, and subscapular skinfold measurement, were predictors for the School Activities domain [F (11, 44)=3.981, P<0.005, R2=0.499].
Therefore, a multidisciplinary approach involving nutritional intervention is essential to improve dietary provision and the nutritional status of children with CP.

Sociodemographic and anthropometric data, including body mass index (BMI)-for-age, MUAC, body fat, triceps, and subscapular skinfold measurement, were predictors for the School Activities domain [F (11, 44)=3.981, P<0.005, R2=0.499].

Poor nutritional status in individuals with severe CP has been shown to negatively impact caregivers' quality of life. Therefore, a multidisciplinary approach involving nutritional intervention is essential to improve dietary provision and the nutritional status of children with CP.
